title: 104_s1471
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Tort Claims Act Malpractice Coverage for Health Centers Extension Act of 1995" and refers to amendments or repeals in the Public Health Service Act. It also includes a section on the permanent extension of a program. SEC. 2. PERMANENT EXTENSION OF PROGRAM. Amends Section 224(g) by removing the last sentence of paragraph (3) and makes conforming amendments to Section 224(k)(1)(A) and Section 224(k)(2). SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF COVERAGE. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF COVERAGE. Amends Section 224(g)(1) by specifying individuals covered as officers, governing board members, employees, and contractors. Section 224(g) (42 U.S.C. 233(g)) is amended to include deeming certain individuals as employees of the Public Health Service for services provided to patients of the entity and potentially to individuals who are not patients, subject to approval by the Secretary. The amendment includes deeming certain individuals as employees of the Public Health Service for services provided to patients of the entity and potentially to individuals who are not patients, subject to approval by the Secretary. This applies to populations served by the entity through community-wide intervention efforts, facilitating service provision to patients, or as required under employment contracts. SEC. 5. APPLICATION PROCESS. The application requirement for deeming an entity or individual as an employee of the Public Health Service under Section 224(g)(1) is amended to include submission of an application to the Secretary for approval. The application must contain detailed information and supporting documentation to verify eligibility. The Secretary will determine if an entity or individual is considered an employee of the Public Health Service within 30 days of receiving an application. This determination will apply for a specified period. The Secretary's determination of an entity or individual as a Public Health Service employee is final and binding in civil actions. The approval process for applications under subsection (g)(1)(D) requires the entity's full cooperation. In civil actions, the Secretary's determination of a Public Health Service employee is final. The approval process for applications requires full cooperation, changing "has fully cooperated" to "will fully cooperate." SEC. 6. TIMELY RESPONSE TO FILING OF ACTION OR PROCEEDING. Section 224 (42 U.S.C. 233) is amended to require the Attorney General to appear in State court within 15 days of being notified of a civil action against certain entities or individuals for damages, advising the court on their status as employees of the Public Health Service. The Attorney General must certify that an entity or individual was acting within their scope of employment. If the Attorney General fails to appear in State court, the civil action will be removed to a United States district court for determination of the appropriate forum for the claim for damages. SEC. 7. APPLICATION OF COVERAGE TO MANAGED CARE PLANS. Section 224 (42 U.S.C. 233) is amended to include a new subsection stating that entities working with managed care plans will be considered employees of the Public Health Service for malpractice coverage purposes. Managed care plans must deem these entities and their personnel as meeting malpractice coverage requirements. Entities working with managed care plans will be considered employees of the Public Health Service for malpractice coverage purposes. Managed care plans must deem these entities and their personnel as meeting malpractice coverage requirements. Any plan found to have violated this subsection will cease to receive Federal funds under title XVIII or XIX of the Social Security Act. The term 'managed care plan' refers to health maintenance organizations and similar entities that contract for the provision of health services to plan enrollees. SEC. 8 amends coverage for part-time providers under contracts to specify qualifications in certain medical fields. SEC. 9 updates due process for loss of coverage procedures. SEC. 10 requires a report on risk exposure of covered entities. The General Accounting Office must submit a report to Congress by December 31, 1997, on the medical malpractice liability claims experience of entities deemed employees under the Public Health Service Act. The report will compare estimated aggregate amounts for obtaining malpractice insurance with and without the Act in effect. The General Accounting Office will consult with experts to prepare a report for Congress on medical malpractice liability claims of entities under the Public Health Service Act. The report will include comparisons of grant reductions under section 224. SEC. 11. AMOUNT OF RESERVE FUND amended to change the reserve fund amount from $30,000,000 to $10,000,000.
